name: Incident Management
description: The tooling and processes enabling an appropriate response to incidents and the alignment with broader incident management frameworks throughout the organisation.

criteria.name: Communications channels and methods during an incident are well understood across the team
RC.CO-3: Recovery activities are communicated to internal and external stakeholders as well as executive and management teams
RC.CO-2: Reputation is repaired after an incident

The tooling and processes enabling ops  to respond appropriately to incidents and align with broader incident management frameworks throughout the organisation. Furthermore, the degree of tie-in with respect to incident management and the SDLC.
Adhoc tooling is available to assist in pinpointing the root cause of issues
Formalised process that is followed across the organisation
Defined 'categories' or 'severities' of incidents, with a clear understanding of what each category means for this service
Structured approach to problem analysis and capture of detail as tailored for the team
Root-cause analysis results for every incident is captured and fed back into SDLC
Regular rehearsals and dry-runs of incident scenarios
RS.MI-3: Newly identified vulnerabilities are mitigated or documented as accepted risks

components.name: Metrics
components.definition: The metrics used to establish the quality of the engineering being delivered.

criteria.name: Well-established metrics for overall service health, including volume and severity of incidents
Well-established metrics for incident response - e.g. time to first response, MTTD, MTTR, no. of escalations (e.g. L1 to L2)
Regular reporting on metrics to surface patterns and opportunities
Cost per incident is well understood (can be modelled, for example, via T&M)
Well-established metrics, with targets for continuous improvement.

questions.definition: What are the major P1/P2 incidents that happened over the last 6 months
What were the nature of the incidents / which systems have been impacted? Any general themes? (e.g. networking, hardware, software)
What are your monitoring and alerting tools / processes?
How are you accessing production? Are you using a jump-box, TPAM, one‐time password?
Do you have audits of all production activity?
Are you aware of all business and/or system specific SLAs/SLOs while fixing production issues?
Do you have any incident runbook and knowledge-base repositories to refer to in case of incident?
What are your on‐duty call process?
What are the communication channel and methods during an incident?
Do you have any specific approach to problem analysis during an incident?
Do you use any tools in particular to pinpoint the root cause of issues? (e.g. Splunk, AppDynamics…)
holding any Incident Retrospective (PIR, Post‐incident review) meeting? How frequent?
Are you rehearsing regularly the processes and resolution steps of past incidents?
Are you gathering any specific health metrics (volume, severity of incidents, number of escalations)?
Any additional advanced metrics such as MTTD, MTTR, number of escalations?
Are you reporting/reflecting on existing metrics to spot any trends/patterns?
Are you consistently determining the cost per previous incidents?
Is there any assurance protocol surrounding the close off of the Incident?
